title: Moviegoers Called ‘Pakistani Terrorists’ For Not Standing Up During National Anthem In Theatre
text:
Does standing up during the national anthem demonstrate patriotism? And not standing up make you anti-national? The debate has been going on for a long time now, but what happened recently has sparked it up all over again.

Four people who went to watch Dhanush-starrer Tamil movie Asuran at a movie theatre in Bengaluru were forced to leave during the intermission for all they did was not stand up during the national anthem.

It is said that the national anthem was played at the beginning of the movie. After a few people didn’t stand up, a lot of them protested, but because the lights were switched off, the protest died down soon.

Don't Miss 26.5 K SHARES 45.1 K SHARES 14 K SHARES 18 K SHARES 6.5 K SHARES

Later, during the intermission when the lights were turned on again, people in the theatre caused an uproar. They were shamed to an extent that they were asked “are you Pakistani terrorists?”

One of the man hurling abuses at the group has been identified as actor Arun Gowda. He shamed men and women for “not sparing 52 seconds for the country.” The video has gone viral on social media.

Disgusted to see youngsters not respecting India and our national anthem ... see the resistance to stand up when being rendered in a theatre ! pic.twitter.com/6Yti6795K0 — Karuna Gopal (@KarunaGopal1) October 29, 2019

The incident has kickstarted the debate again. Here’s how people reacted!

Re the national anthem in theatres situation - YOU'RE NOT ALLOWED TO PLAY THE NATIONAL ANTHEM IN CLOSED ROOMS. I learnt this at Naval Public School in 10th grade. pic.twitter.com/m50l2Nuzfm — Rachita 🌈🐶😴 (@visualfumble) October 29, 2019

I have always felt that there is no greater insult to our National Anthem than it being played in movie Theatres.

Most of the times, some B grade movie will be playing.

The over priced popcorn and water in theatres - Multiplex should be the thing that people should stand up. — Basalelu #ChaloVizagNov3 (@BasaleluPspk) October 28, 2019

I will stand up for my National Anthem irrespective of where it is being played. Having said that I do believe that movie theatre is not a place to play it. Although I would stand for it even then. — shruti (@vyasshruti) October 28, 2019

There is a difference between patriotism and jingoism.

STOP PLAYING NATIONAL ANTHEM IN THE THEATRES. https://t.co/HHC2BmEoW3 — Amon (@leftesla) October 28, 2019

Our supreme court says it is not mandatory to stand in theatres where national anthem is part of the movie. Kindly forgive and forget don't drag it unnecessarily. https://t.co/7JiAdLEDrY — H K🇮🇳 (@HHKHN10) October 29, 2019

Standing up for National Anthem Is Necessary and Should be.

But We should Also think on The Argument that Not Standup For National anthem in Movie Theatre makes them Less Patriot!?

Solution: National Anthem Only Played on Occasions where/When it Respected Properly. — अहमस्मि योधः (@YesImIntolerant) October 29, 2019

National Anthem in movie theatres is so much part of debates today. How many remember that in 60’s each Bollywood movie ended with National Anthem? I was 5yrs old, 1965, and distinctly remember black and white ‘Tricolour’ fluttering across full screen. — @ColSanjayPande (@ColSanjayPande) October 28, 2019

Firstly Playing a National Anthem in Theatres where huge funny things happen is a wrong .

Goons coming & compelling someone to Stand for National Anthem is a stupidity.

Is There any necessary to prove someone Nationalism.

Compelling is prohibited idiots pic.twitter.com/t88VDoONLc — Asgar Shaik👋 (@Asgar7599) October 28, 2019

The incident took place at PVR orion mall.
